Well written and accurate review. Before green screen there was rear screen projection.

Imagine two actors in the back seat of a taxi cab (the cab of course is only a mock up on a movie sound stage), and the camera is looking toward them so that the camera and audience see the rear window.

Rather than green or blue screen, there is a translucent screen behind the taxi which the camera can see and behind the screen is a projector that is showing a movie of a street scene that corresponds to the action at hand. Imagine a sheet with a movie being projected on it.

In other words the camera is photographing two actors with a movie screen behind them.

The really complicated part comes from the fact that the movie camera and the movie projector must be in synch or the camera will record some black frames.

This was the way it was done in the early days before green and blue screen and traveling mattes.

There is more sophisticated (and expensive) software that allows the post production editor to get rid of shadows and miscellaneous flaws that might appear in an imperfect background lighting setup. Any object or flaw that does not overlap the primary subject can be "painted out with green" in post production.

Finally, the main action cannot have any green on it or the back ground will bleed through. One can use any color for a background, but green is usually chosen because green has the smallest presence in human flesh tones.

Right now most people I know resort to heat when often ice would help. I've learned through experience with a bad back which after years of recurring back attacks I now exclusively use ice to treat. I've even discovered I could avert a back attack by icing immediately upon feeling a strain rather than letting it develop.

Heat has its place but among the ordinary non-athletes who don't need to return to the professional playing field, I think ice and its benefits are under-appreciated.

"The result was frequently, at least in the short term, poorer athletic performance. Volunteers were not able to jump as high, sprint as fast, or throw or strike a ball as well after 20 minutes of icing."

But who the hell would ever advise ice before sporting? Not one physical therapist that I know would. It's about time you formally acknowledged your naked disdain for physical therapy, Ms. Parker-Pope. You obviously think you're smarter than the people who actually successfully treat patient after patient.

It makes no sense to apply ice to sore muscles. Sore muscses need warm, wet heat to relax them and improve blood flow. ice works primarily to stop pain and swelling in an acute injury. Sorry to say that this article does not distinguish between the two.

Additionally, for sore muscles, it is good to give that muscle group a day of rest (with stretching and heat, perhaps a different form of exercise; swimming is GREAT). The following day, get back to the exercise that caused the sore muscles. Perhaps more gently ...

A sharp or extreme pain is best treated by ice. Ice followed by heat, ASAP. Preferably warmth, wet heat,

Heat ASAP bring blood-flow to the area. (Chinese medicine would say "brings chi to the area.") Unless pain is extreme, I start with heat. If the heat makes the painful area more painful or even just itchy, ice is a better choice.

If I can't go straight to heat, I alternate heat/ice or ice/heat,; appx. three minuntes each.

Also, rather than pain reliever - which just dulls pain, increasing the change of re-injury - I apply an herbal-mix gel called Arnica gel. i also take Arnica orally as directed by the package. Arnica reduces trauma. It is great on sore muscles.

I also use a product called TrauMed or Traumeel - which is Arnica with additional healing herbs.. Straight Arinca is thought to be useful immediatly following the injury. If you get to addressing your pain afe days after the injury, go for Traumeel. or TrauMed.
Rest and alternating ice and heat packs is often effective for non-chronic strains and muscle soreness. All the clinical gibberish aside, maybe it's the "placebo effect."

My kids took terrible online classes. My daughter, with a 3.9 GPA, is bored to tears and has struggled to complete her work. She hasn't learned and doesn't remember anything from her class. She is late on assignments because, she says, she doesn't face a teacher. She has a B.
Her real teachers have inspired her to help in her community, to work when she didn't want to, and to sweat while planting trees. They've inspired her with their decency, kindness, and sometimes their fashion sense. She likes physics and trigonometry. She learns concepts and won't ever forget her days in these classes. She often goes to school at 7:30 a.m. to get help in trigonometry -- really!
We drove 14 hours to Boise and back to attend a hearing on Tom Luna's proposal. Most of our January trip was made in the dark on narrow, icy, winding 2-lane roads. After staying overnight, we arrived at 1 p.m. for the 3 p.m. hearing. I had 4 teens with me, who chose to miss a day of school to speak at the hearing. The GOP leaders of the Idaho legislature let those who supported the measure cut in the line of people who wished to speak. As you signed up, you had to check your position on the measure. Supporters got to move up in line faster than the many people who opposed. When we spoke at 6 pm., we were given 2 minutes to speak instead of the 3 that had been given earlier.
I told a native Iranian -- this was the first time I ever got a taste of an abuse of power. He said, "It didn't taste very good, did it?''
Of course, many schools are doing ( or not doing...) just that.

A couple years ago, I had a knee injury -- saw an orthopedic doc, was sent to physical therapy.

Naturally they told me the RICE protocol -- rest, ice, compression and elevation. I was miserable and in terrible pain. I live in a cold climate -- it was winter, cold and damp. The last thing I wanted was to put bags of ICE (or frozen veggies) on my aching knee -- just made the pain worse, even intolerable.

But the doc and the physical therapist INSISTED that heat was "bad" and ice would heal me. So I stuck with it for months, getting worse and worse -- chilled, clammy, cold and achy.

Finally, I cracked. I couldn't stand it anymore - and starting applying heat, including long hot baths and heating pads.

My pain IMMEDIATELY responded and improved -- I could become pain-free enough to actually fall asleep. The improved sleep ALONE was curative!

When I told the doc and physical therapist, they were horrified -- basically first laughed at me, then told me how uncooperative I was, and how I'd "never get better with that attitude".

Of course I DID get better -- and quickly. God knows how much MORE quickly had I not wasted months making myself cold, stiff, damp and miserable.
